Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Control of the Electron Nuclear Interaction in NanoElectronic Devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Last Modified Date: 06/15/09 Last Modified By: Daniele Finotello

Abstract
This award supports an international collaboration for research and education among Harvard University and University of Florida (UF) in the USA, University of Basel and ETH (Zurich) in Switzerland, and University of Regensburg in Germany. The main goal of the project is to understand, control, and utilize the hyperfine interaction of electron spins, confined in low-dimensional condensed matter systems, with the nuclear spins of the host lattice. Four emerging themes in condensed matter physics draw particular attention to this topic, making a Network-scale activity timely. Those themes are: i) advances in nanoscale control of matter, e.g. , quantum dots, where electrons interact with far fewer nuclear spins thereby greatly enhancing the effectiveness of hyperfine coupling; ii) emergence of spintronics devices employing the electron's spin rather than charge for future prospects of quantum repeaters, quantum computers, and quantum memory for secure communication and enhanced computation, iii) engineered interactions in novel materials, such as gating and tailoring of band structure, and iv) availability of high-quality fabrication facilities. There are three main thrusts in this Network: i) control of spin and electron-nuclear interaction in III-V semiconductor quantum dots [experiment: Harvard; theory: Harvard, Basel]; ii) coupling of nuclear spins via itinerant carriers (RKKY interaction) and nuclear magnetism in p-doped heterostructures [experiment: ETH, Regensburg; theory: UF, Basel, Harvard]; and iii) electron-nuclear interactions in 13C-enriched nanotubes [experiment: Harvard, theory: Harvard, Basel, UF]. By investigating the interface between fundamental and applied problems in an international environment, this Network contributes to the kind of cross-training of graduate students that is needed for the next generation of device engineers and scientists, perhaps working with quantum-coherent devices. Exchange of students between experimental groups at Harvard and ETH and between theoretical groups at Harvard, Basel, and UF will take place over the course of the project

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major source of decoherence in semiconductor-based qubits is due to  hyperfine coupling between spins of electron and nuclear spins of the host material,  typically, GaAs. Although there is a number of technique that reduce this decoherence, none results in a sufficiently quiet nuclear environment. One bold idea would be to let nuclear spins order into a ferromagnetic state where the noise is minimal. The problem is that direct coupling between nuclear spins is very weak and thus ordering can only occur at unrealistically low temperatures. One of the goals of this project was theoretical modeling of indirect coupling between nuclear spins mediated by conduction electrons. We developed a theory of such coupling that takes into account two major ingredients typical for any heterostructure: Coulomb repulsion between conduction electrons and spin-orbit interaction which imposes correlations between electron's momenta and spins. We found that the combination of these two effects amplifies the effective coupling between nuclear spins such that ordering can occur at temperatures within the reach of current techniques. Although ferromagnetic state of nuclear spins coupled to two-dimensional electrons has not been observed yet, an indirect evidence for the effectiveness of such mechanism has recently been demonstrated by the Basel group (C. P. Scheller et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 112, 066801 (2014)), which observed spontaneous nuclear-spin polarization in GaAs quantum wires below 0.1 K. If this mechanism can also be implemented in quantum-dot qubits, this will be an important step towards quantum computation on a semiconductor-based platform.

While working on the project described above, we realized that one of the most successful theories in condensed matter--the Fermi liquid theory that describe an unified way properties of such diverse many-fermion systems as He3, neutron stars, and conventional metals--has not been generalized to include spin-orbit interaction among electrons. We developed such a generalization in the series of papers. The most interesting outcome of this theory is a prediction of a new type of collective modes--chiral spin waves. Spin-orbit coupling can be thought of an effective magnetic field that acts only on an electron's spin (but not on its charge) which, in contrast to the real magnetic field, depend's on the electron's velocity. A single electron spin placed in a magnetic field precesses around the  direction of the field with the frequency determined by the strength of the field. Precession of a large number of electrons, coupled to each other via arepulsive Colomb interaction, produces a wave--a collective mode whose frequency depends on the wavelength, and also on the strength of the Coulomb interaction. Spin-orbi interaction leads to a similar wave-like effect except for it produces not one but three waves (two transverse and one longitudinal) whose frequencies may increase or decrease with the wavelength. It is convenient to think of these ways as "particles" with masses that can be either positive or negative. We worked out a detailed proposal for detecting chiral spin waves in a semiconductor heterostructure. Hopefully, this proposal will be implemented in the immediate future.
